If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Large; up to 100 mm long; about 160 segments.. The prostomium Broadly rounded anteriorly; two large eyes; occipital tentacle posteriorly.. The setae Bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from about setiger 45 onward.. The parapodia Notopodial lamellae large and auricular in branchial region; lateral membranous pockets between parapodia from about setiger 25 in mature specimens.. The branchiae Long, cirriform; from setiger 2 to setiger 40.. The dorsal features Long ciliated dorsal ridge extending over 28 to 40 segments; membranous transverse ridges on middle segments.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Small; up to 30 mm long; about 90 segments; usually smaller.. The prostomium Anterior margin blunt; posterior end pointed.. The setae Neuropodial bidentate hooded hooks from setiger 10 to 11, about 8 to 10 per neuropodium; two inferior sabre setae in posterior neuropodia.. The parapodia Notopodial lamellae auricular; neuropodial lamellae broadly oval anteriorly, narrower posteriorly.. The branchiae Anteriorly attached to bases of notopodial lamellae; posteriorly free.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Very large; up to 100 mm long; about 200 segments; width ~3 mm.. The prostomium Smoothly conical; median ridge extending posteriorly to setiger 2; eyes absent.. The setae Notopodial and neuropodial capillaries, some with speckled axes; neuropodial hooded hooks from setiger ~30 to 44, bilobed in juveniles, bluntly unidentate in adults; one to two inferior sabre setae from setiger 14 onward.. The parapodia Neuropodium with small oval presetal lobe; postsetal lobe dorsoventrally elongate, with free superior projection in posterior segments.. The branchiae From setiger 1 to posterior end; anterior branchiae completely fused to notopodial lamellae; mid-body notopodium with distal triangular lobe; accessory branchiae as minute lamellae posterior to neuropodia from about setiger 35.. The peristomium Closely applied to lateral margins of prostomium.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Large; up to 80 mm long; ~150 segments; width ~3 mm.. The prostomium Anteriorly pointed; posterior keel to setiger 2; four eyes in transverse row; occipital tentacle absent; peristomial lateral folds enclosing prostomium.. The setae Anterior notosetae numerous winged capillaries with distal punctuations; posterior notosetae few, fine, elongate; notopodial hooded hooks absent; anterior neurosetae winged capillaries; unidentate hooded hooks from ~setiger 40, up to six posteriorly; posterior neurocapillaries reduced to small tuft.. The parapodia Neuropodial lamellae oval anteriorly, deeply notched posteriorly; notopodial lamellae almost completely fused to branchiae anteriorly, progressively separate posteriorly, joined only at base by ~setiger 60; dorsal fold connecting lamellae from mid-body onward.. The pygidium With ventral cushion below anus.. The branchiae From setiger 2 to near posterior end.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 80 mm long; ~200 segments.. The prostomium Anteriorly pointed; four to six eyes in a transverse row; distinct occipital ridge extending to setiger 2.. The setae Bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 30 to 35 onward (up to twelve per neuropodium); bidentate hooded hooks in notopodia from about setiger 60.. The parapodia Notopodial lamellae fused to branchiae in anterior segments; auricular and largely free posteriorly, inferior margin produced ventrally toward neuropodium.. The pygidium Small pygidial cushion, broader than long.. The branchiae Fused to notopodial lamellae anteriorly.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body About 25 mm long; ~100 segments.. The prostomium Sharply pointed anteriorly; erect occipital tentacle posteriorly; two pairs of subdermal eyes; short nuchal bands extending to setiger 2.. The setae Anterior notosetae and neurosetae winged capillaries; punctate setae absent; neuropodial hooded hooks from setigers 16 to 18 onward, replacing capillaries; hooks with three long teeth above main fang; inferior sabre setae absent; posterior notosetae unknown.. The parapodia Neuropodia ear-shaped throughout; notopodial lamellae triangular and laterally placed in posterior region.. The branchiae From setiger 2; anterior branchiae large, strap-like, completely fused to notopodial lamellae; from setiger ~16 onward branchiae and lamellae progressively separating; posterior branchiae narrow-stalked with flag-like distal ends.. The peristomium and first setiger First setiger small; notosetae and neurosetae present.. The posterior region Often missing; posterior characters unknown.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body About 30 mm long; ~90 segments.. The prostomium Bluntly pointed anteriorly; posterior keel extending to setiger 2; four subdermal eyes, often indistinct.. The setae Neuropodial hooded hooks from setigers 15 to 18; notopodial hooded hooks from after setiger 30; hooks with paired teeth above main fang in South African material (two paired teeth).. The parapodia Anterior notopodial lamellae pointed, small on first setiger, increasing to setiger 6 then decreasing; posterior notopodial lamellae subequal; dorsal ridges absent; neuropodial lamellae small, triangular; lateral pouches between neuropodia from about setiger 5 in mature specimens.. The branchiae Long, smooth, tapered branchiae from setiger 2 to 10; longest on setigers 2 to 4; branchiae about three times the length of corresponding notopodial lamellae.. The peristomium and anterior segments Buccal segment partly fused with reduced setiger 1.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Small, thread-like; about 15 mm long; ~60 segments.. The prostomium Depressed; square anterior margin; posterior extension as an inconspicuous plate; keel absent; two pairs of small eyes, indistinct or absent in adults.. The setae Neuropodial hooded hooks from setigers 18 to 19 onward; about five per neuropodium; each hook with a single tooth above the main fang.. The cirri Four pairs; subequal; cirriform.. The parapodia Notopodial lamellae triangular, pointed, subequal except first, which is small; neuropodial lamellae small, triangular, similar in shape to notopodial lamellae throughout, including posterior segments.. The branchiae About 11 to 12 pairs; from setiger 2 onward; smooth, cirriform; uniform in length; two to three times longer than notopodial lamellae.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Large; up to 60 mm long.. The prostomium Bluntly pointed anteriorly; posterior ridge present; enclosed by large wing-like lateral expansions of the peristomium; eyes rarely visible in adults; membranous transverse ridge dorsally behind palp bases.. The setae Winged capillary setae in both rami anteriorly; neuropodial hooded hooks from setiger 9 onward, up to 12 to 15 per neuropodium; hooks with four pairs of teeth above main fang; inferior sabre seta associated with hooks.. The branchiae Three pairs of large pinnate gills on setigers 1 to 3; one or more pairs often lost.. The peristomium Lateral expansions broad, wing-like.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Small; 10 to 20 mm long.. The prostomium Rounded anteriorly; supported laterally by small peristomial ridges; six eyes.. The setae Inferior sabre setae in neuropodia from setiger 12; tridentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 14 to 16 onward and in notopodia from setiger 30.. The parapodia Notopodial lamellae triangular on setigers 3 to 5, becoming smaller and rounded posteriorly; no membranous dorsal crests.. The branchiae Two pairs of pinnate branchiae on setigers 2 and 3 only.. The peristomium Reduced; setiger 1 very small, without branchiae or notosetae.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 45 mm long; about 100 segments.. The prostomium Rounded anterior margin; median keel extending posteriorly to setiger 2; eyes indistinct or absent.. The setae Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 18 to 19 and in notopodia from setiger 50 onward; hooks with four paired rows of teeth above main fang; inferior sabre seta in neuropodia from setiger 18.. The peristomium Erect lamellae fused to notopodia of setiger 1.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 20 mm long.. The prostomium Blunt anteriorly; posterior keel extending to setiger 2; two pairs of eyes, anterior pair small, posterior pair large and comma-shaped.. The setae Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 16 to 18 onward; hooks with four to five paired teeth above the main fang.. The parapodia Notopodia largest on setigers 3 to 4, decreasing posteriorly; low dorsal ridges uniting notopodia from setiger 6; neuropodial lamellae low and oval throughout; membranous genital pockets between neuropodia from setiger 2, conspicuous after about ten segments.. The branchiae Four pairs on setigers 2 to 5; first pair large, papillate; second and third pairs short and smooth; fourth pair tapered with marginal papillae.. The peristomium  setiger 1 Setiger 1 small; broad notopodial and neuropodial lamellae present.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 20 mm long.. The prostomium Anteriorly expanded; posteriorly narrowed into an elevated keel between peristomial folds; two to four small eyes; scattered black pigment flecks.. The setae Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 19 to 21 and in notopodia from setiger 37; hooks with numerous teeth above the main fang; punctate sabre seta in inferior neuropodium from setigers 19 to 23 onward.. The parapodia Notopodial lamellae triangular and pointed, largest on setigers 3 to 5, decreasing posteriorly; low membranous dorsal ridge uniting notopodial lamellae from setiger 5 to 6 for 20 to 30 segments; neuropodial lamellae rounded, initially longer than broad, later oval; genital pockets between neuropodia from setiger 2 for about 20 segments in adults.. The branchiae Four pairs on setigers 2 to 5; first pair pinnate; second and third pairs short and smooth; fourth pair long, smooth, and tapered.. The peristomium  setiger 1 First setiger with small notopodial and neuropodial lamellae.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Thread-like; up to 25 mm long; about 80 segments.. The prostomium Rounded anteriorly; posterior keel extending to setiger 2; four eyes.. The setae Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setiger 15; up to six per neuropodium; hooded hooks in notopodia from setigers 25 to 35; hooks with a single tooth above the main fang; inferior sabre seta in neuropodium from setiger 12.. The parapodia Anterior notopodial lamellae pointed and laterally directed; maximum size on setigers 6 to 9; posterior lamellae smaller and rounded; dorsal ridges uniting lamellae from setiger 20 onward.. The branchiae Four pairs on setigers 2 to 5; first three pairs smooth; fourth pair larger and pinnate.. The peristomium  setiger 1 Setiger 1 small; fused to peristomium.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Thread-like; about 25 mm long; ~60 segments.. The prostomium Bluntly rounded anteriorly; posterior ridge extending to setiger 2; four eyes, second pair large and elongate.. The setae Pluridentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 12 to 14; hooded hooks in notopodia after setiger 40; inferior sabre seta in neuropodium from setiger 12.. The parapodia Anterior notopodial lamellae triangular; largest on setiger 4; lamellae decreasing posteriorly and low, rounded from setiger 8 onward; membranous dorsal ridge across setiger 7 with smaller incomplete ridges on following segments; neuropodial lamellae low and rounded throughout; genital pockets absent.. The branchiae Four pairs on setigers 2 to 5; first and fourth pairs long and pinnate; second and third pairs short and smooth.. The peristomium  setiger 1 Small lateral peristomial folds fused to setiger 1; first setiger reduced.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 170 mm long; ~150 segments; uniformly white.. The prostomium Bluntly spear-shaped; anterior end smoothly rounded; median thickening present.. The setae Setigers 1 to 8 with narrow-winged capillaries in both rami; setiger 9 with few capillaries and numerous modified setae bearing a subterminal expansion before a fine tip; abdominal segments with rows of hooks, each hook with two teeth side by side above the main fang.. The parapodia anterior region Notopodia with low, rounded presetal lips and large tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae; small erect digitiform lobe above notosetae on setigers 1 to 8; neuropodia with smaller lamellae than notopodia; presetal lamella of neuropodium produced ventrally below neurosetae; postsetal lip small except on setigers 7 to 8.. The setiger 9 Short; presetal and postsetal lobes subequal in both rami.. The parapodia abdominal region From setiger 10 onward, rami with equal tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae curving medially; lateral pockets present on several segments after setiger 25.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 30 mm long; distinct reddish to purple transverse band on setigers 5 to 8.. The prostomium Truncate triangular; about as broad as long; paired muscular strands diverging anteriorly to antero-lateral projections.. The setae Setigers 1 to 8 with simple capillary setae in both rami; abdominal segments with rows of hooks, each hook bearing two teeth side by side above the main fang.. The parapodia anterior region Neuropodial lamellae slightly larger than notopodial lamellae; notopodial postsetal lamellae ligulate; erect superior lobe (dorsal cirrus) absent; neuropodial lamellae mainly infrasetal; lamella of setiger 8 markedly enlarged; presetal lamellae absent.. The setiger 9 Short; parapodia reduced; setae similar to those of preceding segments.. The parapodia abdominal region From setiger 10 onward, rami with subequal, tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae, curved medially and pointed distally; lateral pocket-like folds present anterior to some posterior parapodia in adults.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body About 35 mm long; ~40 segments; uniformly pale; red band on setigers 5 to 8 absent.. The prostomium Elongate, 1 to 3 times as long as broad; antero-lateral corners distinct.. The setae Setiger 9 with broad-winged capillaries similar to those of setigers 1 to 8; abdominal segments with hooded hooks bearing two teeth side by side above the main fang.. The parapodia anterior region Notopodia of setigers 1 to 8 with small superior lobe united to a much larger inferior lobe; neuropodia with a tapered inferior lobe.. The setiger 9 Notopodium without superior lobe; neuropodium with a small ventral projection.. The parapodia abdominal region Notopodial and neuropodial postsetal lamellae subequal; oval in outline with constricted bases.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Small; about 7 mm long.. The setae Capillary setae in both rami except neuropodia of middle segments; hooks in both rami from setigers 11 to 15 onward; anterior hooks with slightly flattened tips; middle hooks spoon-shaped; posterior neuropodial hooks with a boss below the excavation.. The branchiae Two pairs; both shorter than palps; first pair dorso-lateral on posterior margin of buccal segment; second pair more dorsal on setiger 1.. The palps Long; lateral in origin.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Black; gregarious; up to 20 mm long; boring in encrusting calcareous algae.. The prostomium Stout, hood-like; overhanging mouth.. The setae Saw-edged capillaries in notopodia of setigers 1 to 12, often absent in middle segments, reappearing posteriorly; capillaries absent from neuropodia after setiger 12; spoon-shaped hooks in neuropodia from setiger 10 and in notopodia from setiger 12; posterior hooks with a boss below the excavation.. The branchiae Four pairs; longer and more slender than palps; first pair dorsal on buccal segment above palps; second pair on setiger 1; third and fourth pairs on setigers 2 and 3; branchial bases progressively wider apart, forming an inverted V.. The palps Lateral in origin.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Gregarious; boring in calcareous algae; up to 15 mm long; about 60 segments.. The prostomium Stout, hood-like; overhanging elongate mouth.. The setae Setiger 1 with neurosetae only; notosetae capillaries to setiger 12, replaced by acicular hooks for ~10 segments, later both hooks and capillaries; neurosetae capillaries on setigers 1 to 7, mixed capillaries and hooks on setigers 8 to 11, hooks only for several segments, then both types reappearing posteriorly; acicular hooks spoon-shaped.. The branchiae Four pairs; longer than palps; first pair immediately above palps; second pair immediately below palps; third pair dorso-lateral on setiger 1; fourth pair lateral on setiger 2.. The palps Short; lateral; arising just anterior to setiger 1.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Elongate; up to 20 mm long; about 180 very short segments; branchiae filamentous.. The prostomium Pointed; one pair of subdermal eyes.. The setae Capillaries in both rami throughout; posterior neuropodia with pointed setae intermediate between capillaries and acicular setae.. The branchiae Very fine filaments; from setiger 1 to near posterior end; anteriorly above notosetae, posteriorly between notosetae and neurosetae.. The palps One pair; large; grooved; arising at junction of buccal segment and setiger 1.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Large; up to 100 mm long and about 1 mm wide; anterior region swollen; body tapered at both ends; anterior segments very short and broad, posterior segments longer.. The prostomium Broadly conical; eyes absent.. The setae All smooth capillaries in both rami; notosetae longer than neurosetae; posterior notosetae extremely long, sometimes as long as body width.. The branchiae Long, filamentous; from setiger 1 to near posterior end; arising immediately above notosetae throughout.. The palps One pair; very stout; grooved; arising at junction of buccal segment and setiger 1.. The buccal segment Triannulate; third annulus distinct.. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Thread-like; about 35 mm long; anterior segments short; posterior segments about as broad as long.. The prostomium Sharply conical; eyes absent.. The setae All saw-edged capillaries; acicular hooks absent.. The branchiae Very slender filaments; present from setiger 1 to posterior end; anterior branchiae arising dorsally within a fusiform interbranchial area extending to about setiger 20; posterior branchiae arising from mid-dorsal line.. The notosetae Present from segment 4; total 19 or more segments bearing notosetae; each seta with a denticulate tip; in posterior segments the denticulate portion elongate and spirally twisted. The branchiae Three pairs; branched; arising on segments 3, 7, and 13. The uncini Commence on segment 5; initially in a single row, later arranged in two rows; each uncinus with three denticles above the main fang in profile view, but three to four arcs of denticles in edge-on view; attachment button absent. The ventral surface Thirteen ventral pads on segments 2 to 15; followed posteriorly by a glandular mid-ventral streak. The cephalic region Eye-spots absent; anterior segments without lateral lobes. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body 6 to 15 mm long; slender; 35 to 40 segments. The reproduction Hermaphrodite. The setiger 1 Notosetae only; winged capillaries. The segmentation Eight thoracic segments; 24 to 30 abdominal segments. The branchial region Branchial lobes each bearing seven radioles; radioles not united by a web; distal pinnules short, followed by a long naked terminal tip. The cephalic  peristomial region Collar absent; peristomial segment forming a triangular ventral lobe fused to the base of the branchial lobes. The notosetae thorax Setigers 2 to 8 with winged capillaries and paleae with long tips. The neurosetae thorax Pick-axe to shaped setae with heart-shaped blades ending in long tips; avicular uncini with striated crests. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Slightly tapered; up to 50 mm long. The palps Short. The notosetae thorax Two types present on setigers 2 to 8; long, slender winged capillaries; paleae with short tips. The neurosetae thorax A row of pick-axe setae with symmetrical blades; a row of avicular uncini with fairly long shafts. The branchial crown Each branchial lobe with multiple radioles; two or more radioles per lobe bearing large subterminal eyes. The collar Present; dorsally notched to form two small dorsal lobes and two large lateral lobes. The thoracic segments Setigers 2 to 8 with notosetae; thoracic neurosetae well developed. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Long, slender worm; lives in a tough, brown, translucent tube. The notosetae thorax Two to three smooth-winged capillaries per fascicle; numerous paleae with rounded blades ending in pointed tips. The neurosetae thorax A row of pick-axe setae with transparent, tapered blades; a row of avicular uncini with fairly broad tails and striated crests. The abdominal setae Notosetae avicular uncini similar to thoracic ones; neurosetae slender-winged capillaries and paleae with blades much longer than those of the thorax. The branchial crown Branchial lobes borne on a long stalk; each lobe with 12 radioles united by a web for about one quarter of their length; each radiole with ~10 pairs of eye-spots located midway along; tips blunt. The collar Divided dorsally and split ventrally; each half notched dorsally to form a small rounded dorsal lobe and a large lateral lobe slanting forward ventrally into a triangular lappet. The thoracic segments Setigers 2 to 8 with both noto- and neurosetae. The collar setae Stout, smooth-winged capillaries arranged in a line. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Slender; up to 50 mm long; commonly boring in old coral. The palps One pair; tapering. The notosetae thorax Two types present on setigers 2 to 8; winged capillaries with normal tapered blades; paleae with rounded blades lacking a distal spine. The neurosetae thorax A row of pick-axe setae with smooth, symmetrical blades; a row of avicular uncini with finely striated crests and very broad tails. The abdominal setae Notosetae avicular uncini similar to those of the thorax; neurosetae of two types to very slender winged capillaries with long narrow blades, and stout paleae with oval blades bearing an abruptly arising slender tip. The branchial crown Branchial lobes borne on a common stalk; each lobe with about 15 to 20 radioles united for roughly one third of their length; free distal portions with small, irregularly arranged lateral eye-spots and fairly long naked tips. The collar Very low; margin smooth and straight; collar continuous with only a shallow dorsal depression and a ventral prominence. The thoracic segments Setigers 2 to 8 with both noto- and neurosetae. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 250 mm long; pale in colour; enclosed in a slender mud tube. The tube Slender; composed of mud. The notosetae thorax Winged capillaries of two lengths; longer and narrower forms and shorter, broader forms present. The neurosetae thorax A row of pick-axe setae with broad, symmetrical blades tapering to pointed tips; a row of avicular uncini, each with a cap of 30 or more minutely denticulate ridges above the rostrum and a short tail. The branchial crown Branchial lobes each with about 10 to 40 radioles; radioles long and slender with short distal tips; gills conspicuously banded with purple. The collar Widely separated dorsally; reflected back dorso-laterally to form four lobes; larger lateral pair ending ventrally in thickened lappets. The thoracic segments Thorax bearing well-developed noto- and neurosetae. The branchial base Without glandular cushions; annular rings present when contracted. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Large, stout species; overall size large; gills often distinctly banded in yellow and brown. The notosetae thorax Winged capillaries of the usual sabellid type. The neurosetae thorax A row of pick-axe setae with long, symmetrical blades; a row of avicular uncini with long, broad shafts and a crest bearing about 20 oblique rows of striations. The branchial crown Radioles united by a web for about one-quarter of their length. The collar Low; widely separated dorsally; attached posteriorly to setiger 2; laterally notched; ventrally produced into a pair of stout lappets. The thoracic segments Thorax bearing typical noto- and neurosetae. The glandular areas A dorsal glandular area extending from the base of the branchial crown to setiger 3 or 4; often divided medially or transversely; continuous with glandular bands on the inner surface of the collar, which curve onto the ventral surface; ventral glandular area sometimes reported as separate. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Slender; up to 15 mm long; body with up to 12 thoracic segments and numerous abdominal segments; tube fragile. The pygidium With a pair of small oval lobes; no eye-spots. The palps Slender. The notosetae thorax Six winged capillaries and six spear-shaped paleae per parapodium. The neurosetae thorax A row of pick-axe setae with plain, symmetrical, pear-shaped blades ending in fine tips; a row of long-shafted avicular uncini with coarsely serrated crests. The abdominal setae Abdominal uncini similar to thoracic uncini; neurosetae consist of three broad-bladed paleae; all setae symmetrical. The branchial crown Branchial lobes each with six radioles; radioles without eye-spots; tips fairly long. The collar Widely gaping dorsally; each half notched posteriorly to form a small rounded dorso-lateral lobe and a large lateral lobe; lateral lobes slant forward beneath the gills and meet medially, giving the collar a long scoop-like appearance supporting the bases of the gills. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Stout; brownish in colour, shading to purple anteriorly. The thoracic uncini With straight tails; crest above rostrum bearing 20 or more minute denticular ridges. The branchial crown Branchial lobes spiral, forming four to six whorls of radioles; radioles decrease in length distally; radiolar eye-spots present. The collar Widely separated dorsally; notched laterally; ending ventrally in rounded lappets. The stylodes Broad; extending backward as flanges along the sides of the radioles; increasing in size distally. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Slender; up to 50 mm long; uniformly pale except for interramal eye-spots. The thoracic uncini With six to eight rows of denticles above the rostrum. The branchial crown Branchial lobes semicircular, not spiral; bearing no more than one flattened whorl of radioles. The collar Widely separated dorsally; low; without lateral notches; divided dorsally and reflected back dorso-laterally; forming small ventral lappets. The stylodes Small; strap-like; one to two times as long as the width of the radiole. The radioles Without marginal flanges. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Large and robust; up to 150 mm long and about 15 mm wide; body shading from brown to purplish anteriorly. The thoracic uncini With finely denticulate crests; necks relatively narrow; tails fairly long. The thoracic notosetae Capillaries of two lengths; shorter capillaries with broader wings than the longer ones. The branchial crown Branchial lobes each with a central axis bearing four to six whorls of radioles; gills uniformly orange-brown or distinctly barred. The collar Widely separated dorsally; not notched laterally; forming a pair of stout triangular ventral lappets. The stylodes Absent. The radioles Outer whorl with double rows of eye-spots; lateral flanges present, formed by continuation of the basal web. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 12 mm long; slightly tapered; 20 to 26 segments. The pygidium With two eyes; without posterior prolongation. The palps Two; long. The abdomen 12 to 18 segments; posterior end with a ventral concavity and lateral flanges extending over about five to six setigers. The thoracic notosetae Winged capillaries; spear-shaped paleae. The branchial crown Branchial lobes each with five radioles; radioles united by a web for more than half their length; distal portions ending in long naked tips. The collar Widely divided dorsally; well developed laterally; shallowly notched ventrally where attached to the lips. The ventral filaments About two pairs; small; rolled inwards; without pinnules. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Up to 20 mm long; about 40 segments. The pygidium Conical; without eyes. The thorax Eight setigers. The abdomen About 32 setigers; posterior eight segments short and flanged to form a spoon-shaped concavity. The thoracic notosetae Three types present on setigers 2 to 8; Four winged capillaries; Five paleae with broad blades and long tips; Three minute-bladed setae barely projecting from the body surface. The branchial crown Branchial lobes each with nine radioles; radioles bearing pinnules with two to three elongated pinnules ventrally; all radioles united by a web for about two-thirds of their length. The collar Divided dorsally and notched to form a pair of small dorsal lobes and a pair of large lateral lobes; lateral lobes slit ventrally and fused to the ventral lips. The sensory organs One pair of eyes and one pair of otocysts located within the collar segment. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Short and rather stout; 5 to 11 mm long; about 26 to 30 segments. The pygidium With a tapered terminal appendage (filiform tail). The thoracic notosetae Three types present; Winged capillaries; Paleae with tapered blades; Short, fine setae with tapered tips and no blades. The branchial crown Each branchial lobe with 6 to 10 radioles plus two elongated ventral filaments; radioles united for about half their length and distally flanged. The collar Well developed; small apposed dorsal lobes; lateral lobes smooth and not notched ventrally. The sensory organs Eyes and otocysts doubtful or indistinct. The thoracic neurosetae Long-shafted hooks; main fang surmounted by two teeth and numerous denticles; with a narrow limb (limbe  times©troite). The abdominal notosetae Quadrangular uncini with six close-set rows, each row bearing five to six teeth above the main fang and basal prow. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Small; about 30 to 40 segments. The pygidium May bear eye-spots. The palps One pair; long and slender. The abdomen Abdominal segments numerous. The branchial crown Each branchial lobe with 4 to 8 radioles; radioles united by a web for about two-thirds of their length and distally flanged; a pair of small ventral radioles without pinnules. The collar Narrowly divided dorsally; straight laterally; united ventrally; margin scalloped. The sensory organs Eyes and otocysts present inside the collar segment. The thoracic neurosetae Hooks with numerous small teeth above the main fang when viewed laterally. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body About 5 to 7 mm long; slender; 25 to 28 segments. The pygidium With a long, slender caudal appendage. The palps One pair; long; slender. The thorax Eight setigers, Setiger 1 with winged capillaries only; Setigers 2 to 8 with notopodial winged capillaries and spathulate setae; neuropodia with four to five long-shafted hooks. The abdomen About 20 setigers; body tapered posteriorly. The notosetae thorax Winged capillaries with blades of normal width; Spathulate setae with blades widening distally and then abruptly tapering to slender tips (palea-like). The neurosetae thorax Long-shafted hooks with a prominent rostrum surmounted by about four arcs of long denticles. The abdominal setae Capillaries with long, slender blades; Hooks Z-shaped or avicular; each with a long rostrum surmounted by closely set arcs of denticles (about 15 in total) and a long manubrium bending back abruptly to form a lightly chitinised base. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Very small; about 3 to 4 mm long. The uncini With four to five rows of teeth; each row bearing about 20 to 25 teeth; basal gouge with three to five divergent prongs. The tube Calcareous; coiled anticlockwise when viewed from above (dextral); with five longitudinal ridges; grooves between ridges bearing transverse slits; typically attached to fronds of algae. The thorax Three thoracic setigers; two rows of uncini on each side. The operculum Incubatory; cylindrical with perforated calcareous walls; opercular lid with a marked rim; basal plate subcircular. The collar setae Present; blades pilose; without basal lobes. The special setae Setae of Apomatus absent on setiger 3. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Large species; up to about 120 mm long; abdomen two to three times longer than thorax; abdomen with approximately 200 to 300 segments. The tube Stout; cylindrical; strongly ridged; calcareous. The operculum Oval; bearing two or four short, branching, antler-like processes. The thoracic uncini Single row of 15 to 18 teeth above the main fang. The branchial crown Four to six whorls of branchial radioles; radioles usually red. The collar Usually blue; divided laterally with a fillet present at each incision. The collar setae With a hispid boss at the base of the blade; spinulation increasing distally. The opercular stalk With small, blunt lateral wings. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Deep-sea serpulid; body details largely concealed within tube. The tube Very distinctive; strongly sculptured with numerous closely spaced transverse ridges; tube robust and highly recognisable. The operculum Conical; covered by a simple, slightly raised chitinous endplate; endplate with distinct rims. The thoracic uncini Saw-to-rasp shaped; about 12 teeth visible in lateral view; anterior fang simple and pointed. The thoracic membranes Rounded; extending posteriorly to the 3rd thoracic segment. The opercular peduncle Smooth; cylindrical; with a clearly visible constriction. The collar chaetae Simple; limbate. The apomatus chaetae Present in the thorax. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Small deep-sea serpulid; body largely concealed within tube; seven thoracic chaetigerous segments. The tube White; opaque; with elaborate star-like peristomes; denticulate keel present; tube surface distinctive and sculptured. The operculum Present; with a chitinous, concave endplate. The collar Non-lobed; edge entire; collar continuous with short thoracic membranes; thoracic membranes ending at the 2nd thoracic chaetiger. The thoracic segments Seven chaetigerous segments. The opercular peduncle Smooth; cylindrical; without wings; no constriction between peduncle and operculum; inserted as the second dorsal radiole on one side. The collar chaetae Two types present; fin-and-blade chaetae and limbate chaetae. The apomatus chaetae Present in thorax. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters are as follows The body Elongate; with 62 to 64 chaetigers bearing biramous parapodia; deep ventral longitudinal groove extending along entire body length, flanked by paired ventro-lateral ridges. The prostomium Triangular; tapering anteriorly; ending in a clavate tip; prostomial eyes absent; lateral eyes absent. The parapodia Biramous; each with a short triangular prechaetal lobe and a small digitiform ventral cirrus. The branchiae Long; cirriform; present from chaetiger 2 to the last chaetiger at the base of the anal funnel. The proboscis Not protruded. The nuchal organs Large; present as conspicuous lateral depressions. The anal region Anal funnel well developed; spoon-shaped; annulated; laterally slightly compressed; about twice as long as wide at base; ventral slit present, originating in the posterior third of the body; rim of anal funnel bearing slender papillae of variable length, posterior papillae shorter than anterior ones. The chaetae Simple capillary chaetae only; notochaetae generally longer than neurochaetae; chaetae of chaetigers 1 to 2 long, straight, directed anteriorly but not strongly curved. Identify the polychaete species.

If the diagnostic characters include a globose, smooth carapace with strongly convex velvety tomentose dorsal surface; frontal margin with two short lobes separated by a sinus; infraorbital margin triangular and visible dorsally; vertically folding antennules; long chelipeds about 1.8 times carapace length with pearly white gently curved fingers; pereopods tightly fitting and tomentose; and a truncate triangular telson, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a globose carapace with strongly convex tomentose dorsal surface; distinct branchiocardiac grooves with deep pits; infraorbital margin not visible dorsally; massive basal antennular article; chelipeds about 1.5 times carapace length with fingers bearing blunt interlocking teeth; and a rounded telson longer than wide, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a subovate carapace with smooth strongly convex dorsal surface bearing short stiff setae; distinct branchiocardiac groove; triangular exorbital tooth with longer suborbital tooth; antennal basal article with distolateral spinule; subequal chelipeds with sparsely granular propodus; and fingers slightly longer than palm, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a subovate carapace much wider posteriorly; rough dorsal surface with scattered long setae; deep branchiocardiac and cervical grooves; cornea highly reduced to a point; long setose chelipeds nearly twice carapace length; arched dactylus with proximal depression; and fingers shorter than palm with strong teeth, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a longitudinally ovate carapace distinctly wider posteriorly; well-defined regions separated by deep grooves; dense tomentose setation; long sharp rostrum with pseudorostral spines; massive antennular base without fossae; tomentose chelipeds with spined carpus; and a triangular telson with sharp distal tip, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a bright orange subrectangular carapace with well-defined regions; absence of true orbits replaced by a depressed orbital complex; reniform cornea wider than peduncle; spinose lateral margins; brightly colored long chelipeds with multiple spines; and a triangular telson fitting into maxilliped bases, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a longitudinally rectangular sculptured carapace; long rostrum with very long downward-curved pseudorostral spines bearing accessory spines; inflated gastric, branchial and cardiac regions; long ocular peduncles; and subequal chelipeds longer in males, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a subrectangular carapace widest at the branchial region; well-defined granular gastric patches; oblique branchiocardiac grooves extending ventrally; short downward-directed rostrum; strongly expanded propodus forming a subchela with marginal teeth; and a triangular telson fitting into maxilliped bases, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include an elongated smooth carapace wider anteriorly; blunt median dorsal ridge; triangular whitish rostrum; U-shaped orbits with narrow orbital spines; long strongly deflected fingers exceeding palm length; and a bluntly triangular telson lodged in the sixth abdominal somite, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include an urn-shaped carapace widest posteriorly; smooth pitted dorsal surface; indistinct branchiocardiac grooves; blunt triangular rostrum; subcylindrical smooth chelipeds shorter than carapace length; and a very short bluntly triangular telson, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a transversely subovate carapace strongly convex and yellow; anterior two-thirds covered with concentric rows of large maroon submammillate tubercles; bilobed frontal margin with wide V-shaped notch; massive dissimilar chelipeds with crested dorsal margins; molariform teeth on right chela; and a triangular telson, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a transversely ovate carapace with coarsely granular dorsal surface; ornamentation of bright orange tubercle rows; trilobed frontal margin; massive subequal chelipeds with sharper teeth on left chela; and a bluntly triangular telson shorter than wide, what will be the species?

If the diagnostic characters include a subquadrate glabrous carapace expanding posteriorly; narrow V-shaped supraorbital margin; poorly pigmented cornea visible dorsally; slender glabrous chelipeds with fingers longer than palm; and a bluntly triangular telson shorter than wide, what will be the species?

If a crab shows a subrectangular carapace with dull brown finely granular dorsal surface, posteriorly expanding lateral margins, long slender ocular peduncles with poorly pigmented cornea, unequal red chelipeds with blunt-toothed dactylus, and a bluntly triangular telson half as long as wide, what will be the species?

If a crab has a subhexagonal carapace with orange pitted plates of fused granules, trifid rostrum, laciniated carpal teeth, bright orange unequal chelipeds with dark fingers, and a granular triangular telson, what will be the species?

If a crab possesses a transversely rectangular dark orange carapace, shallow branchial grooves, unequal massive chelipeds with a large white meral spine and tricoloured fingers, and a bluntly triangular telson half as long as wide, what will be the species?

If a crab is characterized by a transversely rectangular glabrous dark orange carapace with a red gastric spot, eroded anterolateral teeth, massive unequal chelipeds with spined merus and carpus, and a triangular telson shorter than width, what will be the species?

If a crab has a subhexagonal rounded carapace, four anterolateral teeth, heterochelous chelipeds with granular spine on carpus, dark brown fingers, and a bluntly triangular telson about 0.7 times as long as wide, what will be the species?

If a crab shows a reddish-orange transversely subovate carapace with poorly defined regions, sinuous anterolateral margins with granular tubercles, subcylindrical chelipeds with white fingers, and a triangular telson shorter than width, what will be the species?

If a crab possesses a subcircular globose carapace with tuberculate dorsal surface, bilobed frontal margin, long ogive-shaped telson over twice as long as wide, and very long straight cheliped fingers, what will be the species?

If a crab has a subrhomboidal globose carapace with lamelliform anterolateral crests, sharp crested cheliped palms, gently curved compressed fingers, and a blunt triangular telson, what will be the species?

If a crab shows a pyriform carapace covered with thick brown tomentum, longitudinally folded antennules, inflated palm with acuminate fingers, and a rounded triangular telson, what will be the species?

If a crab is identified by a pyriform convex carapace with gastric and cardiac spines forming a hexagonal pattern, massive male chelipeds with carinate margins, and a blunt triangular telson as long as wide, what will be the species?
If a crab has a pyriform carapace with thick tomentum, straight pseudorostral spines, carinate chelipeds, slender curved fingers, and a short triangular telson, what will be the species?
If a crab shows a pyriform carapace with long serrated pseudorostrum, numerous sharp dorsal spines, slender unequal chelipeds with short fingers, and a semicircular telson, what will be the species?

If a crab possesses a heart-shaped carapace with extremely inflated branchial regions, long beak-like pseudorostrum, very long chelipeds with short dentate fingers, and a triangular telson, what will be the species?
If a crab shows a pyriform granular carapace with prominent orbital spines, slender subequal chelipeds, smooth straight fingers, and a semicircular telson, what will be the species?

If a crab is characterized by a transversely subcircular carapace with strong gastric spines and bifid rostrum, long ocular peduncles, massive male chelipeds, and a rounded notched telson, what will be the species?

If a crab has a glabrous subcircular carapace with extremely long protogastric spines, numerous branchial spines, long slender chelipeds with spinose margins, and a rounded telson with median spinule, what will be the species?

If a crab possesses a transversely subcircular tuberculate carapace with multiple gastric and branchial spines, massive male chelipeds with many dorsal spines, and a truncate triangular telson, what will be the species?

If a crab shows a pyriform carapace densely covered with conical spines, long bifid rostrum with multiple spines, spinose chelipeds, and a rounded telson with paired submedian spines, what will be the species?

If a crab shows a subhexagonal glabrous carapace with poorly defined regions, three anterolateral teeth, massive subequal chelipeds with a large inner carpal spine and truncate triangular telson shorter than wide, what will be the species?

If a crab has a subhexagonal glabrous carapace, massive olive-brown chelipeds with large inner carpal spine, long slender fingers with pits, and a bluntly triangular telson about 0.6 times as long as wide, what will be the species?

If a portunid crab has a subhexagonal carapace with six frontal teeth, six anterolateral teeth, massive spiny chelipeds, broadened fifth pereopod, and a wide bluntly triangular telson, what will be the species?
If a portunid crab shows a strongly setose subhexagonal carapace with six anterolateral teeth, massive rugose chelipeds, setose pereopods, and a bluntly triangular telson, what will be the species?

If a portunid crab has a smooth subhexagonal carapace with six frontal and six anterolateral teeth, massive rugose chelipeds with red-tipped fingers, flattened ovate propodi, and a wide bluntly triangular telson, what will be the species?

If a crab possesses a subquadrate flattened carapace with spatulate bifid rostrum, unequal chelipeds with inflated major palm, and a bluntly triangular telson longer than wide, what will be the species?
If a crab has a hexagonal smooth carapace with three small anterolateral teeth, sparsely setose pereopods bearing movable spines, and a wide bluntly triangular telson, what will be the species?

If a sea star has five long flat strap-like arms, bold black mottled dorsal coloration, inferomarginal plates with multiple spines, and lacks large bivalve pedicellariae near the mouth, what will be the species?
If a sea star has five flat strap-like arms, blunt-tipped paxillae, large bivalve pedicellariae near the mouth, and pinkish coloration in preserved specimens, what will be the species?
If a sea star shows tightly packed central paxillae, three inferomarginal spines per plate, adambulacral pedicellariae, and Indo-Pacific distribution, what will be the species?
If a sea star possesses ten arms, loosely packed cylindrical paxillae exposing papular areas, T-shaped inferomarginal plates, and two types of pedicellariae, what will be the species?

If a holothurian has yellow to brown body coloration, thin rough integument, triradiate perforated rods, and curved rods in tail, what will be the species?
If a large sausage-shaped holothurian shows fusiform rods, anchors, racquet plates, phosphatic deposits, and cosmopolitan deep-sea distribution, what will be the species?
If a holothurian has swollen body, very short pink tail, rubbery integument, and lacks calcareous ossicles in body wall, what will be the species?
If a holothurian shows white body with red patches, strong calcareous ring with bifid posterior projections, and diverse anchor and spatula ossicles, what will be the species?
If a holothurian has small body size, whitish caudal region, phosphatic deposits, and only perforated rod ossicles in the tail, what will be the species?

If a small deepwater shark has seven gill slits, extremely large eyes, comb-like lower teeth without serrations, and a single dorsal fin far anterior to caudal fin, what will be the species?

If a stingray has rounded disc, rough dorsal surface, large dorsal tail spine, conspicuous ventral fold, and grey disc with black blotches, what will be the species?
If a small reef fish has 12 dorsal spines, pink body with white spots and yellow fins, and lives among Pocillopora branches, what will be the species?
If a reef fish shows orange body, filamentous caudal lobes, elongate pelvic fin in males, and Indian Ocean distribution, what will be the species?
If a cardinalfish is semi-transparent with blue head spots, black caudal base spot, and shallow reef habitat, what will be the species?
If a snapper has deep body, crescentic vomerine teeth, reddish-brown body with blue lines on head, and yellow fins, what will be the species?
